I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.   In  February  2011,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  $1  billion 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to fund operational improvements for urban water supply 
during 2011–2020.1 The MFF provides access to financing to many water companies to help 
them improve their operations and expand their water supply systems, including intake works, 
production transmission, and distribution.2 The facility addresses water as a limiting factor for 
growth and inclusiveness by expanding water supply services to peri-urban areas, ultimately 
increasing competitiveness and assisting the transformation of cities and towns to keep pace 
with rapid urbanization. This capacity development technical assistance (TA) is being processed 
in parallel with the MFF to help the Government of Viet Nam improve water supply services.3 
The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  In 2007, the government formulated a progressive legal framework4 that requires water 
companies to equitize5 and operate on business principles that would improve their performance. 
The  government’s  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan,  2011–20156 includes  water  sector 
objectives:  (i)  identify  water  as  a  limiting  factor  of  growth,  and  support  local  economic 
development by developing modern urban infrastructure, and (ii) improve the quality of life and 
health of people by providing access to safe water. The country program for the water sector in 
ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 for Viet Nam is consistent with these policies.7  
 
3.  The  TA  aims  to  build  capacity  in  selected  water  companies  to  operate  on  sound 
business  principles  in  order  to  efficiently  fulfill  their  service  obligations  and  establish  a 
partnership with the private sector on a voluntary basis. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Viet  Nam  has  reached  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  7.C  target  to  halve  the 
proportion of people without access to safe water by 2015. With rapid population growth and as 
the country transitions to become part of the global economy, the government recognizes the 
need  to  improve  water  sector  efficiency  to  meet  the  increasing  demand  for  water.8 The 
responsibility for urban infrastructure financing and operation rests with local governments. The 
legal framework (footnote 4) enables local governments and water companies to increase tariffs 
to full cost recovery with an allowance for subsidies.9 However most local governments lack the 
capacity to manage the complexity of water services. Considerable capacity building is needed

5.  The  TA  will  contribute  to  the  capacity  development  of  selected  water  companies 
borrowing under the MFF to improve service to users, specifically targeting improved business 
planning and financial sustainability, nonrevenue water (NRW) reduction, energy efficiency, and 
water safety plans.10 The TA will assist water companies define service contracts with local 
governments (as owners of the water companies and regulators of the water services) and 
users. The service contracts will include qualitative and quantitative key performance indicators, 
defined in the business plan, as a basis for regulation by contract, in the absence of an 
independent  regulator.  The  TA  will  assist  in  strengthening  the  corporatization  process  to 
increase the accountability and performance of water companies, and to enable private sector 
participation in different forms, including PPPs. The TA will build capacity at the level of (i) 
government and water companies to support the design and implementation of the  National 
NRW  Reduction  Program,11 which  defines  ambitious  targets12 for  NRW reduction from the 
current national average of 30% and, (ii) the local government and water companies to support 
financial sustainability, through water tariff increases and the enforcement of the legislation.13 
 
6.  The TA supplements ongoing efforts by development partners in the water sector. ADB 
has successfully moved financing for water supply from ADB's Special Funds concessional 
lending terms to the ordinary capital resources LIBOR-based lending facility, as a prelude to 
private sector and commercial financing. Japan initiated a large public–private partnership (PPP) 
program in Viet Nam. The World Bank is assisting the government in several cities through 
water supply and sanitation investments, mostly funded by concessional loans. Through grants, 
Finland  is  supporting  water  supply  and  sewerage  projects  in  small  towns  in  the  northern 
provinces.  The  ADB  project  team  for  the  TA  is  coordinating  with  the  Water  Operators 
Partnership Program (managed by ADB) to strengthen water companies through twinning and 
additional capacity building. The TA supports the implementation of water safety plans by the 
World  Health  Organization  and  Business  Management  Training  for  Managers  of  Water 
Companies financed by Partners for Water (Netherlands) with the Viet Nam Water Supply and 
Sewerage Association, to ensure the relevance of the TA to Viet Nam’s water sector. 
 
7.  The ADB Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020 focuses on the theme of water security.14 
Improving water security for a rapidly growing population requires the efficient use of available 
water resources and effective demand management. The ADB assessment, strategy, and road 
map for Viet Nam’s water supply and sanitation underscores the importance of efficiency gains 
and the private sector in bridging the water supply–demand gap.15  
 
8.  The TA will assist the government and the water companies in developing capacity for 
planning,  regulating,  and  providing  water  supply  services.  The  TA  will  also  provide  the 
instruments needed to assess the performance and the monitoring and evaluation (M&E) of the

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact will be an improved institutional framework for water supply services in Viet 
Nam. The outcome will be improved business practices of selected water companies, serving as 
best practice examples for the Viet Nam water sector.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The overall objectives of the TA are to improve the performance of water supply services 
and  to  make  water  companies  more  accountable  and  efficient.  Capacity  development  will 
support new investment made in water supply, particularly by the MFF. The TA will have three 
specific  targets,  which  are  linked  to  three  outputs:  (i)  promote  policies  through  capacity 
development of the water companies to ensure the operation using sound business principles, 
and to enable a business environment conducive to partnerships with the private sector; (ii) 
support the government in implementing the National NRW Reduction Program (footnote 13), 
through pilot program, that will be upscaled in subsequent tranches of the MFF; and (iii) train 
government  agencies  in  establishing  and  maintaining  effective  M&E,  particularly  the  water 
program financed under the MFF.  
 
11.  The TA will assist water companies in formulating business plans, service contracts, and 
NRW reduction plans. The experience gained through TA implementation will be consolidated in 
proposals comprising contract and business plan templates, planning guidelines for NRW and 
water conservancy, and generic procedures for operation and maintenance.  
 
12.  The TA has three separate but interlinked outputs. 
(i)  Output  1:  Improved  performance  and  accountability  of  selected  water 
companies. Up to three water companies will be selected to prepare business 
plans and establish service contracts with local governments (owners) for the 
benefit of users. The contracts will outline the level of service, and target 5–10  
key performance indicators from benchmarking to ensuring a sound regulation by 
contract. The water companies will each set up a customer service department; 
monitor  complaints;  report  business  performance  to  users;  and  implement 
policies for water safety plans, energy efficiency, NRW, and asset management. 
The  TA  will  support  selected  water  companies  to  implement  international 
accounting  standards,  to  increase  private  sector  participation  through  PPP, 
obtain a credit rating, and transition from a one-member limited company to a 
joint stock company with possible public listings to access the capital market to 
finance additional capital expenditure. The TA will help the central and local 
governments  better  understand  options  available  in  setting  and  enforcing 
appropriate tariffs in exchange for improved operations and increased level of 
service by the water companies.  
(ii)  Output  2:  Introduction  of  pragmatic  procedures  for  implementing  the

to define adequate methodologies for the National NRW Reduction Program.16 
Up  to  three  water  companies17 will  be  selected  to  pilot  the  National  NRW 
Reduction Program to define a model feasibility study report for financing through 
official  development  assistance  or  PPP.  The TA  will  review  options for  cost 
recovery mechanisms to finance the National NRW Reduction Program for the 
central and local governments and water companies.  
(iii)  Output 3: Support for monitoring and evaluation mechanisms for water 
supply services in Viet Nam. Availability and access to reliable information on 
the system is a critical requirement for implementation of the MFF water sector 
investment program. The TA is an integral part of ADB support to establish M&E 
mechanisms for the water sector, using the water companies financed as pilots 
under  the  MFF.  The  TA  will  develop  M&E  indicators,  based  on  the  project 
management implementation system from the project administration manual of 
the water companies financed under the first and second tranches of the MFF. 
The  TA  will  assist  MPI,  the  MFF  coordinating  agency,  in  managing 
implementation and coordinating with line ministries and agencies involved in the 
water sector, such as the Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Finance, Office of 
Government, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Ministry of Natural 
Resources and Environment, and State Bank of Viet Nam.  
 
13.  In order to implement the three outputs, the TA will focus its activities at three levels:  
(i)  Water companies. Activities include capacity development to (a) provide direct 
assistance for formulating business plans and annual forecasts; (b) define the 
contents and key performance indicators for service contracts; and (c) promote 
understanding  of  the  concept  and  implications  of  a  service  contract,  the 
obligations of service delivery, and asset management.  
(ii)  Provincial government. Capacity building activities to (a) clarify the role of the 
provincial people’s committees as the ―client‖ in service contracts with water 
supply  companies;  (b)  support  the  people’s  committees  in  assuming  their 
responsibility as regulator; (c) monitor technical and financial performance; and 
(d) ensure that water companies are fulfilling their obligations in terms of water 
supply, that meets government standards 24 hours a day at adequate pressure. 
(iii)  Central  government.  Activities  include  the  training  of  agencies  and  line 
ministries  to:  (a)  consolidate  experience  with  the  water  company  service 
contracts  and  business  planning  process  into  (draft)  national  guidelines  and 
future  training  programs;  and  (b)  identify  the  issues  and  requirements  for 
improving water supply services in coordination with the Ministry of Construction, 
which  oversees  urban  water  supply;  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  which 
oversees government pricing and lending policies; and the Ministry of Planning 
and  Investment  (MPI),  as  the  coordinating  agency  for  the  MFF  and  water 
companies under the Viet Nam Water Supply and Sewerage Association.  
 
14.  The two recently equitized water companies, Quang Tri Water Company (QTWC) and 
Dak Lak Water  Company will be selected for the first TA output, as proposed during the 
management review meeting for the second tranche of the MFF to provide additional support. 
Other water companies for Output 1 and 2 will be selected by ADB in collaboration with the 
implementing agency and the line Ministries. The TA builds on MFF experience with project

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000, of which $1,100,000 equivalent will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility 
and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
space, counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency and QTWC will be the implementing agency. QTWC is 
corporatized and fully owned by the Quang Tri Provincial Peoples Committee (QTPPC). In the last 
10 years, QTWC and QTPPC benefitted from several donors funded projects, including Mekong 
Water and Sanitation Program with UN-Habitat, Second Provincial Water Supply and Sanitation 
Project under ADB (L1514-VIE) and the recently approved Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor 
Town Development Project (L2969-VIE) with ADB. QTWC is also borrowing under the second 
tranche of the MFF and was cleared by ADB for financial management and capacity procurement 
assessment. As implementing agency, QTWC will coordinate with the Ministry of Construction to 
implement output 2 of the National NRW Reduction Program, and with MPI (the MFF coordinating 
agency) for output 3 on M&E for the MFF. Coordination will be bolstered by three stakeholder 
workshops  that  will  present  and  discuss  major  project  outputs  and  policy  issues,  review  TA 
progress, and provide direction for strategy formulation. The TA will also finance a workshop on 
water safety planning in Viet Nam and selected workshops in the region within the budget allocated. 
 
17.  The TA will finance international consultants (estimated 36 person-months) and national 
consultants  (52  person-months)  from  May  2013  to  December  2014.  ADB  will  recruit  all  the 
consultants as individual consultants, in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The skills required under the TA are too broad to be 
provided by one firm. Consultants must be specialized in business planning, service contracts, 
service performance, finance and PPP, community participation, water safety plans, NRW, and 
M&E. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time) and be handed over to QTWC at TA completion. ADB will manage the 
recruitment of consultants and procurement of equipment and seek QTWC’s concurrence prior to 
recruiting consultants or purchasing equipment. The TA outputs, including knowledge products and 
services, will be disseminated to intended users through workshops, electronic reports, website 
publication, and other means to be specified in a knowledge dissemination and communication 
plan. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).

1.  During preparation of the technical assistance (TA), the project team identified 16 water 
companies participating in the first two tranches of the multitranche financing facility (MFF). A 
shortlist of up to six water companies (3 for business planning and another 3 for nonrevenue 
water reduction) will be agreed at the kick off of the TA.

2.  Team leader and deputy team leader—business planners. Among the four business 
planners:  One  will  be  selected  as  team  leader  and  one  as  deputy  team  Leader,  The 
international  team  leader  should  have  (i)  15  years  of  experience  in  the  operation  and 
management of urban water supply systems, preferably including the policy aspects of urban 
services  management;  (ii)  experience  in  the  conduct  of  feasibility  and  sector  studies  in 
Southeast Asia, preferably including Viet Nam; and (iii) demonstrable experience in leading 
teams for interdisciplinary projects. He will be assisted by a national deputy team leader with at 
least 10 years experience in the water sector in Viet Nam. They will have overall responsibility 
for team management, study guidance, delivery of outputs, and quality control. Responsibilities 
include the following: 
 
(i)  Assume  overall  responsibility  for  the  delivery  of  the  project,  coordinate  and 
manage the team of consultants, liaise with government and with development 
partners to ensure compatibility and to avoid duplication and inconsistency in 
approaches.  
(ii)  Assess  the current situation  in  urban  water  supply  systems;  conduct further 
research  and  interviews  with  government  officials  and  development  partner 
representatives; formulate detailed program outputs with an updated work plan in 
close coordination with the Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Planning and 
Investment, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB); finalize the selection of the 
pilot provinces and towns; and ensure formal written agreements.  
(iii)  Monitor  the  preparation  of  project  outputs  and  deliverables,  particularly 
procedures manuals on nonrevenue water (NRW) reduction, ensuring policy and 
presentational consistency and maintaining quality control.  
 
3.  Business planners. Each of the two international business planners (including the team 
leader, assisted by the two national business planners (including the deputy team leader) will be

Appendix 3  11 
assigned to up to three water companies. The planner will draft a 3-year service contract (in the 
form of a business plan) based on 5–10 key performance indicators selected for the project 
management  information  system  under  the  (MFF).1 The  business  planner  will  prepare  the 
service contract and the business plans. Tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare annual and 3-year business plans and service contracts between the 
owner and regulator (provincial people’s committee) and service providers that 
include the review of (a) the water quality sampling program, (b) the occupational 
health and safety program, (c) standard operating procedures; (d) operation and 
maintenance  manuals,  (e)  the  energy  efficiency  and  management  program; 
(f) the connection policy; (g) the customer complaint management policy, and 
(h) the public information program. 
(ii)  Briefly  review  progress  over  previous  year(s)  in  terms  of  improvements  of 
operating performance and service quality. 
(iii)  Define priorities over the subsequent 3 years to improve operating performance 
and quality of service. 
(iv)  Propose  a  staff  development  and  training  program  and  other  activities  to 
enhance capabilities and performance of operations staff at all levels. 
(v)  Identify issues that might delay or complicate the achievement of the goals of the 
service plan. 
 
4.  Financial and public-private partnership specialists. The specialists will work with a 
maximum of three water companies and assist them in implementing a financial information 
system to monitor MFF implementation. The specialists will (i) define a road map for the water 
companies to move to international accounting standards, and obtain credit ratings for future 
public listing; (ii) develop a private sector development framework; and (iii) provide input into the 
MFF on water tariff road maps and shortcomings of the legislation. 
 
5.  Community participation specialists. The specialists will liaise with nongovernment 
organizations locally, especially the Fatherland Front and the Women’s Union, to develop a 
reporting system based on ISO 24512, the Citizen Report Card, or on any other accepted 
system to assess the level and quality of service received by service users. The specialists will 
use the social assessment report prepared during project preparation to look at affordability and 
willingness to pay for an improvement in service provided. The specialists will also review the 
work of or develop the measures to be applied to the low income group of users.  
 
6.  Water  safety  plan  specialists.  The  specialists  will  support  the  development  of 
guidelines for preparing water safety plans, and assist the water utilities in preparing water 
safety plans in accordance with the guidelines.  
 
7.  Nonrevenue  water  specialists.  The specialists will define the methodology for the 
National NRW Reduction Program through public, private, or public–private partnerships, and 
prepare  a  model  feasibility  study  report  for  a  maximum  of  three  water  companies.  The 
specialists will develop a financing mechanism to recover the cost of implementing the National 
NRW Reduction Program in a suitable manner.

8.  Monitoring and evaluation specialists. The  specialists will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Develop criteria for benchmarking, performance evaluation (report cards giving 
scores on selected important parameters), and performance rating system (like 
the credit rating system used in the finance sector) of service providers based on 
the analysis of similar systems in other countries, especially in Asia and current 
services in Viet Nam. 
(ii)  Collect  relevant  data,  apply  the  approved  criteria,  and  produce  periodic 
performance evaluation (report cards) and overall performance ratings of various 
service providers. 
(iii)  Institutionalize  systems  of  publications  and  dissemination  of  comparative 
performance evaluation (report cards) and performance ratings of various service 
providers to the wider public so that citizens demand better services from service 
providers. 
(iv)  Develop  suitable  systems  through  policy  interventions  and/or  refinement  of 
implementation arrangements to encourage efficiency improvement and better  
service delivery to citizens by service providers. 
(v)  Develop suitable policy interventions for encouraging private sector participation 
in water supply to improve managerial efficiencies and enhance investment. 
(vi)  Organize  capacity  building  programs  for  important  stakeholders  and  service 
providers  including  visits  to  well  managed  utilities  in  the  country  and 
internationally, and encourage service providers to group together for mutual 
learning, experience sharing, and forming associations, as appropriate. 
 
Reporting and Deliverables 
 
9.  Reports  will  be  prepared  in  English  and  Vietnamese  to  facilitate  government 
understanding and decision making. Reports will be submitted in electronic and paper forms. All 
data and analyses will be consolidated and provided to the government in electronic form. The 
following reports will be prepared: 
 
(i)  inception report, summarizing the key issues on preparedness of urban water 
supply companies for commercial operation and confirming the TA work plan; 
this will be the basis for discussion at the inception workshop; 
(ii)  business plan and draft service contract—one for each selected city; 
(iii)  performance indicators to assist the central government, Ministry of Construction, 
and Ministry of Planning and Investment in guiding and monitoring progress  with 
sector policy and targets; 
(iv)  model feasibility study report for NRW reduction to be used to prepare NRW 
reduction projects; 
(v)  final report for output 1; 
(vi)  final report for output 2; 
(vii)  final report for output 3; and 
(viii)  dissemination paper and PowerPoint presentation on the TA findings. 
 
10.  Three copies of each report (in English) will be submitted to ADB and five copies (in both 
Vietnamese and English) to the executing agency. The reports should discuss all aspects of the 
terms of reference to a level of detail appropriate for the given TA component. Each report 
should have a maximum of 50 pages without appendixes.

Appendix 3  13 
11.  The consultants will present key findings in a number of workshops and seminars, with 
participants from  the central  and  provincial  governments,  the  executing  agency,  other key 
agencies,  local  communities,  and  ADB.  Tripartite  meetings  will  be  organized  after  the 
submission and review of the inception report and the draft final report. The consultants will 
assist ADB in preparing the draft TA report. 
 
12.  The following workshops or seminars are planned: 
 
(i)  inception workshop—to present the inception report and update the scope and 
work plan of the project; 
(ii)  midterm  review  workshop—to  review  project  progress,  initial  outcome  and 
findings, and update the implementation plan; 
(iii)  water safety plan workshop—to present the guidelines and prepare the water 
safety plans for the selected water companies; 
(iv)  final dissemination workshop—to present and discuss the results of the work in 
selected cities;  
(v)  Selected workshops in the region—to sponsor water sector representatives in 
Viet Nam to attend the Asia Pacific Water Council in Thailand in 2013. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
